description: From Middle English: the form poitral is from central/Parisian French poitrel, "introduced into English apparently by Caxton"; the older form peitral (Middle English peitrel, paytrel, etc) was borrowed from Anglo-Norman peitral; both are from Old French poitral (modern French poitrail).

entries.meaning: (historical) A piece of armor for a horse's chest; the  breastplate of a horse's armour or harness.
